question: Now you come back.
answer: That's a fine chick.

question: Fine as May wine.
answer: Except she live on the hill and got a grandma.

question: I better not come in.
answer: I ain't stupid.

question: I mean it's late, baby.
answer: I know where you're going.

question: I'm going to bed. I gotta work tomorrow, need my rest.
answer: What for? I ain't white and I don't put out.

question: Sheeet, you ain't. I had aplenty.
answer: ...That isn't a whore? That's alright. Baby, take your time. Sophia's not going anywhere. I told you to walk, don't run.

question: Shhhh! I don't like women that talk.
answer: Who wants to talk?

question: Don't you know, you can't hump the Bogart.
answer: Eat lead, coppers. Bang, bang. You're dead.

question: Naw, you missed me, copper. Try this on for size.
answer: I forgot to tell you I'm wearing a bulletproof vest.

question: The hell you are.
answer: I'm tired of always playing the cops. I wanna be Bogart sometimes.

question: You're too small to be Bogart.
answer: I'm not too short to be Cagney.

question: Ahhh! You got me, you dirty, filthy, rotten, stinking copper, only a low-down yellow rat bastard would shoot a man in the back.
answer: He use to be a big shot.

question: You like 'em scrambled soft or hard, sweetie?
answer: C'mere.

question: Sweetie, they're almost ready.
answer: You hear me, girl?

question: You the man.
answer: You better believe it.

question: You evil this morning.
answer: What's your story, baby? Feed me. Yeah, girl; that's your story. When you gonna holler "rape," sister?

question: Me?
answer: You will, baby -- if the time come.

question: Lemme feed you, sweetie, while they hot.
answer: Sure wish your mama and papa could see you now. And that ofay you gonna marry.

question: Sure wish your mama and papa could see you now. And that ofay you gonna marry.
answer: Malcolm, you can be anything you want. You got class and you're smart.

question: All them books you read and you still don't know nuthin.
answer: I do know I love you. Oh, Malcolm, I love you. Please, there's no one around. Now?

question: Let's go.
answer: Why? Is it because of your white gal? Folks say you're running around town with her.

question: Save it, baby. Save it for Mr. Right, 'cause your grandma's smarter than ya think.
answer: She raised me, my mother died when I was six. Is your mother alive?

question: Did you hear me say come in?
answer: There's no point in fighting about it. I'm sorry. May I sit down?

question: As you nice enough to ask, we'll git you one.
answer: It's the same questions, Mrs. Little. Since the death of your husband--

question: Murder.
answer: -- there is a serious question as to whether --

question: These are my children. Mine. And they ain't no question. None.
answer: I think sometimes, Mrs. Little, candor is the only kindness.

question: Get out.
answer: Your control over your children, therefore--

question: Did you hear me?!
answer: You'll regret this, Mrs. Little.

question: Who is he, man? Whut's he do?
answer: Sit down. We ain't fixing to eat you. You look brand new in town. Pretty handy with a bottle.

question: He had it coming.
answer: What they call you?

question: Red, and I ain't no punk.
answer: You better not be. Cause if a cat toe you down in this town, you better stand up or make tracks.

question: That's a fact. What you do, boy?
answer: I'm working trains. Selling.

question: Bet you like that shit.
answer: Keeps me out of the army.

question: When they want your ass, won't nothing keep you out.
answer: Not this boy... I ain't fighting their war. I got my own. Right chere. Heard tell you're a good man to know.

question: Heard where?
answer: Where I come from. Boston.

question: Sombitch and I ain't never been to Beantown.
answer: Man's rep travels.

question: How 'bout that?
answer: My papa taught me one thing

question: Is your papa West Indian?
answer: No, my mama. She's from Grenada.

question: Where can I get a hold of you?
answer: YOU can't. I'll get a hold of you.

question: Lemme write it down for you.
answer: Don't never write nothing down. File it up here, like I do. 'Cause if they can't find no paper they ain't got no proof. Ya dig?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Boy, look me in the face.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Why?

question: 'Cause I want in. And it don't take a lot to know you there, daddy.
answer: I got me a little run to make.

question: Can I run with you, Mr. Archie?
answer: I like your heart and I like your style. You might just do, Little. Lessen you got to git back to that train job.

question: I done told the man what he could do with his train.
answer: When?

question: Just now.
answer: Come on, baby. We going shopping... Just the middle button, baby. Just the middle one.

question: What?
answer: Frisk me, baby. Give me a real pat down.

question: It's yours, baby. Put it on.
answer: Solid, daddy.

question: Okay, baby. Now you outfitted. You ready to tackle the street?
answer: Let 'em come. I'm ready.

question: I told you less paper, less trouble.
answer: I'm working on it.

question: It hit?
answer: Nnnnnnn!

question: Ain't nuthin' in the world to give you that real deep cool. Like girl. You there?
answer: I'm there, daddy. Wheww. I'm cool enough to kill.

question: Bet you are.
answer: You got any money.

question: I thought you said we were going to the movies last night.
answer: I say a lot of things.

question: And like a fool I believe it.
answer: Do your job, Get me a bourbon on the rocks and a pack of Lucky's.

question: You know that gal?
answer: Mind your own goddamn business ... She comes in a lot?

question: 'Bout every other night, Red.
answer: With him?

question: If she got eyes, she do.
answer: Is she hooking?

question: Not yet. But the way things going, that boy gonna turn her out any day.
answer: Shut up, bitch.

question: Shut up, bitch.
answer: Don't do that.

question: Daddy, where's my money?
answer: What you talking?

question: You owe me six big ones. 1, 2, 8 hit, didn't it?
answer: You din't have no 1, 2, 8.

question: Was you that high? Old man, I threw the slats at you. I said to combinate me.
answer: You never had it.

question: The bitch was there.
answer: Shit, what else she gonna say?

question: Then skip it, man. But you slipping, baby. You done slipped. Oh, sit down, man. What you tasting? I'm buying.
answer: I ain't drinking hot piss with you. Come on, Sam.

question: You're a damn liar.
answer: It's me or you, ain't it, Pops?

question: You know it.
answer: I'll give you back the 600.

question: I don't want your money.
answer: I'm wearing, Archie.

question: There's two guns on you.
answer: And every cat's watching, ain't they? It's a toe-down.

question: That's what it is. Walk on out.
answer: Let Billie finish.

question: Yeah and get a slave, too, huh, baby?
answer: I ain't doing bad.

question: Man, the name musicians ain't got shit. How you gonna have something? I need a stake, a bundle, a grand. My woman can't afford it; my homey ain't got it. How about you baby? What you got?
answer: Jesus, Red, she's just a kid.

question: Yeah. This rich ofay, like he's 60. I give him a bath on Friday.
answer: So what about him?

question: So? The man got silver, china, rugs--
answer: Might be all right.

question: Might be, shit. Man, I know this town. I got my own fences. Who the hell are you? Who put you in charge?
answer: You want to be the head man?

question: That's right.
answer: Head nigger in charge?

question: I'm the man.
answer: Okay, baby. Let's flip for it. Flip this.

question: Don't never try to cross someone who ain't afraid to die.
answer: You the man!

question: All right. We'll start with Old Talcum Powder. You draw the house, where everything is. You and Peg go out and buy them tools like I told you. We hit tonight on account of in the daytime some of us got that high visibility. Ya dig?
answer: What did you do, Homey, palm it?

question: Yeah.
answer: Jesus Christ, Homey, you are nuts.

question: Preacher, take your tin Jesus and the Virgin Mary, both, and shove 'em.
answer: I know how you feel. Like you want to lay down and die.

question: Who the hell are you?
answer: Put it in a cup of water. It's nutmeg.

question: Man, what do you want?
answer: You need something. It's not a reefer, but it'll help some.

question: Man, get outa my face. I ain't nobody's punk.
answer: Sit down or it might knock you down.

question: If you ain't trying to punk me, what's your hype?
answer: I can show you how to get out of prison. And it's no hype.

question: Talk, daddy, I'm listening. Hey that ain't bad. You got some more?
answer: That's the last stuff you'll ever get from me.

question: What did you give it to me for then?
answer: 'Cause you needed it. 'Cause you couldn't hear me without it.

question: What in the hell are you talking about?
answer: I think you got more sense than any cat in this prison. How come you are such a fool?

question: You ain't lying.
answer: When you go busting your fists against a stone wall, you're not using your brains. Cause that's what the white man wants you to do. Look at you.

question: Man, you been locked up too long, everybody conks. All the cats.
answer: Why? Why does everybody conk?

question: Cause I don't want to walk around with my head all nappy, looking like--
answer: Like what? Looking like me? Like a nigger?! Why don't you want to look like what you are? What makes you ashamed of being black?

question: I ain't said I'm ashamed. Leggo. I got to wash it out.
answer: Let it burn. Maybe you'll hear me then.

question: Man, you better get off me.
answer: Sure, burn yourself, pain yourself, put all that poison into your hair, into your body -- trying to be white.

question: Man, I don't want to hear all that.
answer: I thought you was smart. But you just another one of them cats strutting down the avenue in your clown suit with all that mess on you. Like a monkey. And the white man sees you and he laughs. He laughs because he knows you ain't white.

question: Who are you?
answer: The question is, who are you? You are in the darkness, but it's not your fault. Elijah Muhammad can bring you into the light.

question: Elijah who?
answer: Elijah Muhammad can get you out of prison. Out of the prison of your mind. Maybe all you want is another fix. I thought you were smart.

question: I'm staying.
answer: Me too.

question: What you sniffing around for? I told you I gave you your last fix.
answer: I ain't never seen a cat like you. Ain't you scared talking like that in front of an ofay?

question: What's he gonna do to me he ain't already done?
answer: You the only cat don't come on with that "Whatcha know, daddy" jive; and you don't cuss none.

question: I respect myself. A man cuss because he hasn't got the words to say what's on his mind.
answer: Tell you this

question: Don't con me. Don't try...
answer: Okay, okay.

question: Don't con me.
answer: What do you do with your time?

question: I read. I study. Because the first thing a black man has to do is respect himself. Respect his body and his mind. Quit taking the white man's poison into your body
answer: That's what Mama used to say.

question: Your mama had sense because the pig is a filthy beast
answer: Come on, daddy, pull my coat. What happens if you give all that up? You get sick or somethin'? I pulled a hustle once and got out of the draft.

question: I'm telling you God's words, not no hustle. I'm talking the words of Elijah, the black man's God. I'm telling you, boy, that God is black.
answer: What? Everybody knows God is White. What for?

question: Did you ever study anything wasn't part of some con?
answer: What the hell for, man?

question: Go on, fool; the marble shooters are waiting for you.
answer: Okay, okay. Show me, man.

question: That's bullshit. That's a white man's book. Ain't all these white man's books?
answer: They sure ain't no black man's books in here.

question: Then what you telling me to study in them for?
answer: You got to learn everything the white man says and use it against him. The truth is laying there if you smart and read behind their words. It's buried there. You got to dig it out.

question: Man, how'm I gonna know the ones worth looking at?
answer: I'll pull your coat, daddy. Cause lots of these can't nobody read, be he black or white or a Ph.D. with their suspenders dragging the ground with degrees.

question: Man, I'm studying in the man's book. I don't dig half the words.
answer: Look 'em up and and out what they mean.

question: Where am I gonna start?
answer: Start at the beginning. Page one, the first one. Here--

question: Aardvark, noun. An earth pig; an ant-eating African mammal. Man, that sounds like the dozens.
answer: Read it and keep on reading. If you take one step toward Allah, He will take two steps toward you.

question: Take 'em. I don't smoke no more. Ole Pete ain't much in the head, but he can lay in there with the wood.
answer: Lemme tell you about history

question: You pitch, baby; I'll ketch.
answer: The first men on earth were black. They ruled and there was not one white face anywhere. But they teach us that we lived in caves and swung from trees. Black men were never like that.

question: This a helluva game. Somethin's going on. What? How bout that?
answer: Sure, white man throw us a bone and that's supposed to make us forget 400 years.

question: A black man playing big league ball is something.
answer: I told you to go behind the words and dig out the truth. They let us sing and dance and smile -- and now they let one black man in the majors. That don't cancel out the greatest crime in history. When that blue-eyed devil locked us in chains -- 100,000,000 of us -- broke up our families, tortured us, cut us off from our language, our religion, our history.

question: Little.
answer: No. That's the name of the slave-master who owned your family. You don't even know who you are. You're nothing. Less than nothing. A zero. Who are you?

question: I told you we are a nation, the lost Tribe of Shabazz in the wilderness of North America. Allah has sent us a prophet, a black man named Elijah Muhammad. For if God is black, Malcolm--
answer: Then the devil is white.

question: I knew you'd hear me. The white man is the devil. All white men are devils.
answer: I sure met some.

question: Have you ever known a good white man in all your life? Think back, did you ever meet one who wasn't evil? The body is a holy repository.
answer: I will not touch the white man's poison

question: A Muslim must be strikingly upright. Outstanding. So those in the darkness can see the power of the light.
answer: I will do it.

question: But the key to Islam is submission. That is why twice daily we turn to Mecca, to the Holy of Holies, to pray. We bend our knees in submission.
answer: I can't.

question: For evil to bend its knee, admit its guilt, implore His forgiveness, is the hardest thing on earth--
answer: I want to, Bembry, but I can't.

question: --the hardest and the greatest.
answer: I can't.

question: For evil to bend its knee, admit its guilt, implore His forgiveness, is the hardest thing on earth--
answer: I want to, Bembry, but I can't.

question: --the hardest and the greatest.
answer: I don't know what to say to Allah.

question: Have you ever bent your knees, Malcolm?
answer: Yeah. When I was picking a lock to rob somebody's house.

question: Tell Him that.
answer: I don't know how.

question: You can grovel and crawl for sin, but not to save your soul. Pick the lock, Malcolm; pick it.
answer: I want to. God knows I want to.

question: Are there any questions? I see this has become a struggle between good and evil. Satan has a question.
answer: Yes it is, Chaplain Gill. But I wouldn't want to say which one of us is what.

question: Why don't you just ask your question?
answer: You've been talking about the disciples. What color were they?

question: I don't think we know for certain.
answer: They were Hebrew, weren't they?

question: That's right.
answer: As Jesus was. Jesus was also a Hebrew.

question: Just what is your question?
answer: What color were the original Hebrews?

question: I told you we don't know for certain.
answer: Then we don't know that God was white.

question: Now just a moment, just a moment--
answer: But we do know that the people of that region of Asia Minor, from the Tigris-Euphrates valley to the Mediterranean, are dark-skinned people. I've studied drawings and photographs and seen newsreels. I have never seen a native of that area who was not black.

question: Just what are you saying?
answer: I'm not saying anything, preacher. I'm proving to you that God is black.

question: We're not American, we're Africans who happen to be in America. We were kidnapped and brought here against our will from Africa. We didn't land on Plymouth Rock, brothers and sister. Plymouth Rock landed on us. Put an end to your begging. No more "Please, Mr. White Man, Lawdy boss, brush me another crumb from off your table, kindly, sir." We are a nation, a great nation and don't need a thing from them.
answer: I got to hand it to you, Homey. That's the best preacher hype I ever did hear.

question: It isn't a hype, Shorty. And I meant what I said
answer: Come on, baby. I don't pay that shit no mind.

question: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad says you should pay it all your mind. If you got a mind.
answer: Baby, I love you. Take it easy, greasy. How about a snort?

question: I've been clean for twelve years, Shorty.
answer: You is something, Homeboy. My trouble is -- I ain't had enough stuff yet, I ain't et all the ribs I want and I sure ain't had enough white tail yet.

question: How's the rest of the gang? You seen anyone?
answer: Well, Sammy's dead. Yeah, fell over in the bed with a chick twenty years younger than him. Had twenty-five grand in his pocket.

question: Git the hell away, you bitch, I'll pay you tomorrow.
answer: Hello, Archie.

question: My man, Red. Come on in, man. Hey, I can't make it.
answer: Take it easy, baby.

question: That really you, Red?
answer: You saved my life, Archie. Running me out of Harlem. When I think how close we came to gunning each other down, I have to thank Allah.

question: I wasn't gonna shoot you, baby. It was just my rep, that's all. And don't shit me now, but did you have that number? Tell me.
answer: I don't know. It doesn't matter. The thing is we got to get you back on your feet.

question: Yeah. I got a couple a new angles ain't been figured yet. All I need's a stake and a chance--
answer: Can you use a few bucks? I ain't got much, but--

question: No, man, I'm doing okay. Thanks.
answer: Take it easy. Lay down and don't think about it.

question: Yeah.
answer: You could of been something, Archie, but the devil got to you.

question: The Sister wonders if the Brother knows what Harriet Tubman did between taking souls to the Promised Land?
answer: What?

question: She ate.
answer: Sure I'll speak to your class. But I'm a hard man on women. You want to know why?

question: If you want to tell me.
answer: If you want to tell me.

question: I see your point.
answer: So it is not a matter of the breeding conditions or preparation of the meat. The meat itself is foul.

question: Could we sit down someplace?
answer: I'm sorry. I've had you on your feet for hours.

question: You've been on your feet for days. And didn't even finish your salad.
answer: That's something I haven't done in fifteen years.

question: What?
answer: Sat down with a pretty girl and had an ice cream soda.

question: How do you like it?
answer: Delicious.

question: There's nothing to talk about.
answer: 0h, yes, there is. I know a lot about you. Brother Bembry briefed me.

question: Oh? Purely scientific interest I'm sure.
answer: You're from Detroit, near where I come from. You majored in education at Tuskegee. You're studying nursing and having trouble with your family.

question: I can handle it.
answer: They want you to quit the Muslims or they won't pay your tuition, isn't that it?

question: You have enough worries of your own.
answer: No, good Sisters are rare. We need every one. Tell me something

question: Why do you ask?
answer: Just an idle question.

question: If it's just idle, I won't answer it.
answer: How old are you, Betty?

question: There's a few things you don't know about women, Brother Malcolm. They're possessive and vain.
answer: Are you?

question: And dogged when I set my mind to something.
answer: What have you set your mind to?

question: I'm from Muslim Temple 7. Where is he?
answer: What's your name, feller?

question: I'm Minister Malcolm X. Two witnesses saw him brought in. He was not brought out.
answer: You heard the Sergeant. Outside.

question: Take a look out that window. I intend to see Brother Johnson.
answer: Who the hell are they?

question: Brothers of Brother Johnson.
answer: Eddie, let's see that blotter. But you can't see him. You ain't his lawyer.

question: Until I'm satisfied Brother Johnson is receiving proper medical attention, no one will move. Only a pig could do a thing like that.
answer: Watch your tongue, boy.

question: Sit down, son.
answer: Mr. X, I was out there tonight. I saw what you did. I want to be a Muslim. I ain't never seen a Negro stand up to the police like that.

question: Do you know what it means to be a true Muslim?
answer: Not exactly, but I want to be one, like you.

question: I admire your enthusiasm but you should never join any organization without first checking it out thoroughly.
answer: Mr. X, I won't make you out a liar.

question: If I surprise you, let me explain. Menial work teaches us humility.
answer: Let me do it then.

question: No, each of us must relearn that work is the only worthwhile thing. Allah has given you a great gift. Use it wisely, never forgetting that we are nothing, while He is all.
answer: Allah Akbar.

question: Yes.
answer: I'm in Detroit.

question: I know.
answer: At a gas station. Will you marry me?

question: Yes.
answer: Did you hear what I said?

question: Yes I did. Did you hear my answer?
answer: I think so. Can you catch a plane?

question: Yes. Did you eat?
answer: I love you. It won't be easy.

question: Just hold me.
answer: It will be rough.

question: Hush your mouth.
answer: I'll be away a lot.

question: You're with me even when you're away.
answer: What do you think?

question: The simplest thing in the world
answer: I must emphasize at the outstart, that the Honorable Elijah Muhammad is not a politician, so I'm not here this afternoon as a Republican, nor a Democrat, not as a Mason nor an Elk, not as a Christian nor a Jew, not as a Catholic nor a Protestant, not as a Baptist nor a Methodist, not even as an American. For if I was an American the problem that confronts our people today would not exist. So I stand here as what I was when I was born What kind of black people does the Honorable Elijah Muhammad speak for? Black people who are jobless... the black masses who are poor, hungry, and angry, the black masses who are dissatisfied with the slums and ghettos in which we have been forced to live... the black masses who are tired of listening to the promises of white politicians to correct the miserable living conditions that exist in our community... the black masses that are sick of the inhuman acts of bestial brutality practiced by these semi-savage white policemen that patrol our community, like the occupation forces of a conquering enemy army... the black masses who are fed up with the anemic, Uncle Tom leadership set up by the white man to act as a spokesman for our people and to KEEP US SATISFIED AND PACIFIED WITH NOTHING! If the black man cannot go back to his own people and his own land, Elijah Muhammad is asking that a part of the United States be separated and given to the Muslims so they can live separately.

question: Yes sir. As you know, during slavery time, the slavemasters named most of the so-called Negroes in America after themselves. Mr. Elijah Muhammad teaches us once you come into the knowledge of Islam, you replace your slave name with an X. Since we've been disconnected, cut off from our Eastern culture for so long that we don't know the names we originally had, we will use X until we get back to the East.
answer: Mr. X is a demagogue. He has no place to go, so he exaggerates. He's a disservice to every good law-abiding Negro in the country. Can I ask you a question?

question: Please, go ahead.
answer: Mr. Malcolm X, why do you teach black supremacy? Why do you teach hate?

question: For the white man to ask the black man if he hates him is just like the rapist asking the raped, or the wolf asking the sheep, "Do you hate me!" The white man is in no moral position to accuse anyone of hate. I'll talk about "progress" in a minute, but let me finish with my brother.
answer: You put it very well.

question: You left one phrase out. Another educated Kneegrew said to me and I quote
answer: Entirely.

question: Well, I have this to say. Do you know what a Negro with a B.A., an M.A. and a Ph.D. is called -- by the white man? I'll tell you. He's called a nigger. Don't you want to hear about the Field Nigger?
answer: Let him finish.

question: Long day. Long night. Long year. Long ten years.
answer: Because you're in trouble.

question: How do you know?
answer: Dear heart, because I know you.

question: I don't want to bring my troubles home. You know that.
answer: I'm not made of glass.

question: I just want to sit here and be still.
answer: We've never had a fight. Not a real one. But we're going to have one right now if you don't talk about it.

question: Talk about what?
answer: The talk is everywhere!

question: There's always talk, always been talk, and always will be talk. Don't they say how I'm trying to take over the Nation, how I'm getting rich off the Nation?
answer: We'll get to that, too, but this isn't just talk any more.

question: There are always slanders, always lies. You're reading the devil's lies. Can't you see they're trying to bring us down, bring down the Messenger.
answer: "Both women, in their 20's, charged they had had intimacies with Elijah Muhammad since 1957..."

question: I was going to talk to Bembry about it tonight.
answer: To Bembry? Is Bembry your friend?

question: Woman, have you lost your mind? What's the matter with you?
answer: No, what's the matter with you? Wake up! Are you so dedicated that you have blinded yourself? Are you so committed you cannot face the truth? Bembry is the editor of the newspaper you established. Ask him why your name hasn't been in "Muhammad Speaks" in over a year? Ask him why you rate front page in every paper in the country, but not a single sentence in your own.

question: I'm not interested in personal publicity. Our people know what I'm doing.
answer: Do you know what Bembry is doing? You're so blind, everyone can see this but you!!!

question: Bembry saved my Life. The Honorable Elijah Muhammad saved my life.
answer: A long time ago. You've repaid them many times over. Ask them why they have new cars and houses full of new furniture.

question: Is that what this is about? Material wealth?
answer: What do we have, Malcolm. A broken-down jalopy and the clothes on our backs. We don't even own our own home. What about our children? What about me? You don't even own life insurance.

question: The Nation will provide for you and the children if anything happens to me.
answer: Will they? Are you sure? Are you sure or are you blind?

question: What do you want me to do? Our people need me.
answer: We need you too!

question: What do you want me to do?
answer: Open your eyes, you can face death 24 hours a day; but the possibility of betrayal never enters your mind. If you won't do that for yourself do it for us.

question: Another one?
answer: How long has this been going on?

question: All day since you and Betty left. Brother Minister, I have to level with you. They gave me a mission. But I couldn't do it. I love y'all.
answer: What mission?

question: To wire your car so it would explode when you turned the ignition. The Ministers say you are spreading untruths about the Messenger. The Ministers say you are a great hypocrite, Judas, Benedict Arnold. The Ministers say your tongue should be cut out and delivered to the Messenger's doorstep.
answer: What does Sidney say?

question: I'm with you, Brother Minister.
answer: No. You'll be marked for death.

question: Let me die then.
answer: I won't let myself come between you and your father. Go home.

question: You're my father.
answer: And don't come back. Because 1964 threatens to be a very explosive year on the racial front, and because I myself intend to be very active in every phase of the American Negro struggle for HUMAN RIGHTS, I have called this press conference, this morning in order to clarify my own position in the struggle -- especially in regards to politics and nonviolence. In the past I thought the thoughts, spoke the words of the Honorable Elijah Muhammad, that day is over. From now on I speak my own words, and think my own thoughts. Internal differences within the Nation of Islam forced me out of it. I did not leave of my own free will. But now that it has happened, I intend to make the most of it. Now that I have more independence of action, I intend to use a more flexible approach toward working with others to get a solution to this problem. I do not pretend to be a divine man, but I do believe in divine guidance, divine power, and in the fulfillment of divine prophecy. I am not educated, nor am I an expert in any particular field, but I am sincere, and my sincerity is my credentials. I'm not out to fight other Negro leaders or organizations. We must find a common solution, to a common problem. I am going to organize and head a new mosque in New York City, known as the Muslim Mosque, Inc. This gives us a religious base, and the spiritual force necessary to rid our people of the vices that destroy the moral fiber of our community. Our political philosophy will be black nationalism. Our economic and social philosophy will be black nationalism. The Muslim Mosque, Inc. will remain wide open for ideas and financial aid from all quarters. Whites can help us, but they can't join us. There can be no black-white unity until there is first some black unity.

question: Get some sleep.
answer: You have to sleep for three. I'm sorry. I haven't been the best husband or father.

question: Shhh!
answer: Families shouldn't be separated. I'll never make another long trip without you and the kids. We'll all be together.

question: Dear heart, I love you.
answer: We had the best organization that black people ever had and niggers ruined it. Walk out the back, dear. Hurry. There's nothing to be afraid of. It might be a little cold. Hang on. We'll be fine.

question: Brother Earl.
answer: Malcolm, where are you? We've been calling all over the city.

question: I'm gonna try and get some work done tonight.
answer: Let some of us come down there.

question: No, that won't be necessary. I'll be all right.
answer: I wish you'd listen to us. What about the meeting tomorrow? We need to frisk people.

question: I don't want folks to be searched, it makes people uncomfortable. If I can't be safe among my own kind, where can I be? Allah will protect me.
answer: Stop calling us. Leave us alone. Leave us alone. I'll kill you. I'll kill you.

question: Betty it's me. It's me.
answer: Malcolm, they keep calling, threatening us. I'm going crazy, when is this going to stop?

question: Don't answer the phone. It's all right. It's all right. Nothing is gonna happen to anybody.
answer: Dear heart, where are you?

question: At the Hilton. The girls asleep?
answer: I just put them to bed. Can we come to the meeting tomorrow?

question: Ma'am, I'm fine. May Allah bless you. Is the program ready? Why not? You've had ample time, you and the sister. Folks are sitting out there _today_, not next week, expecting to hear our program. Has the Reverend called? Is he going to show?
answer: Reverend Chickenwing called last night and said he wouldn't be able to attend.

question: So now we have no opening speaker? Why wasn't I informed last night?
answer: I called Sister Betty, she didn't tell you?

question: Since when do you start telling Sister Betty my business? Since when? She has nothing to do with this. You tell me, not her, not anybody else.
answer: I assumed...

question: What did I tell you about assuming? Benjamin, you better go out there and explain why the program isn't ready today. Sister, please go with the brother.
answer: Brother Minister, what is wrong?

question: The way I feel, I ought not to go out there today. In fact, I'm going to ease some of this tension by telling the black man not to fight himself -- that's all a part of the white man's big maneuver, to keep us fighting amongst ourselves, against each other. I'm not fighting anyone, that's not what we're here for.
answer: Let's cancel.

question: Is my family here yet?
answer: Down front as always.
